title.narrative: SKILLS FOR LIFE AND WORK

description.narrative: Government and private sector partners have increased the provision of skills for life, learning, employability and decent work for adolescents through both formal and non-formal pathways, particularly in the most vulnerable and violent contexts., which contributes to Cross Sectoral - Gender Discriminatory Roles And Practices, Learning, Skills, Participation And Engagement. UNICEF aims to achieve this through Advocacy And Communications, Advocacy And Public Engagement, Developing And Leveraging Resources And Partnerships, Partnerships And Engagement: Public And Private, Systems Strengthening And Institution Building, Systems Strengthening To Leave No One Behind. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: By 2025, children and adolescents, especially the most vulnerable, have increased access to equitable and inclusive quality education opportunities leading to development, improved learning outcomes and skills for life and work.

related-activity.ref: 2850/A0/06/882 QUALITY EDUCATION AND SKILLS FOR LIFE AND WORK

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: Government and private sector partners have increased the provision of skills for life, learning, employability and decent workfor adolescents through both formal and non-formal pathways, particularly in the most vulnerable and violent contexts.

description.narrative: UNICEF Mexico positioned itself as a key partner for the Vice-Ministry of Upper Secondary Education by collaborating significantly in the strategies to improve academic achievement, based on the results of a national academic evaluation of 800,000 students. UNICEF applieddigital solutions to recover adolescents’ foundational skills in the context of school re-opening that are aligned with the national curriculum and with content co-created by the;MoE, reaching over 55,000 students. Work continued on promoting life skills and employability skills development in formal and non-formal settings, fostering active adolescent participation and girls’ leadership. | Status:On-track | As-of Date:26/01/2022
